LM-FOR-33-ITR-401 Sprinkler & Hydrant hydrostatic test
Guidelines
Guidelines understood - Pass once read
Guidelines: Fire Sprinkler Systems – 1600kPa or 400kPa above the maximum static pressure for a duration of 2 hours (Check notes on Construction Drawing for nominated test pressure)
Fire Hydrant Systems (Low Rise) – 1700kPa or 15 times the design pressure for a duration of 2 hours (Check notes on Construction Drawing for nominated test pressure)

Fire Hydrant Systems (High Rise) – 1050kPa at the highest hydrant in the pressure stage being tested If pressure reading is being taken at the booster, determine the height difference in metres between the top hydrant and the booster and add 10kPa per metre of static pressure to this figure with a minimum test pressure of 1700kPa If in doubt please seek clarification from the Construction Supervisor or the Design Manager

Fire Indicator Panel
Latest consented drawings checked & referenced
Drawing & Revision #
Area clear, tidy and accessible
Attach Photos/Comments below if any issues & send report to Builder
Are visual indicators and controls not less than 750 mm from the floor
Are visual indicators and controls not more than 1850 mm from the floor
Connected to Brigade - Is the fire indicator panel clearly visible and readily accessible within the designated building entry point or the fire control room
Not Connected to Brigade - Is the fire indicator panel in a secure location and clearly visible and readily accessible to authorized personnel
Accessibility
Is the fire indicator panel obscured by a door (if No, continue to CLEARANCE)
Is the door marked in a contrasting colour to the general colour scheme with the words “FIRE PANEL” in letters not less than 50mm high
Is the door absent of locks
Where the door reduces the CIE sounder sound level below the CIE requirement, means are provided to give the required sound level outside the covering door
A minimum clearance is maintained from the enclosure as shown
Power sources
Is the battery enclosure located such that the batteries are readily accessible for inspection
Are the connecting leads to the battery clearly labelled to reduce the possibility of reverse connections to the battery
The battery is not be tapped for intermediate voltages
All connections are made using suitable connectors
Sub-Indicator Panels
The SIP shall only serve areas on one level of a building unless - Pass once below considered
(a) The SIP serves the entire building
(b) All zones connected to the SIP are readily accessible without leaving the area served by the SIP; or
(c) The location of each zone in alarm at the SIP can be identified at the designated building entry point
Where the SIP serves the entire building, it shall be installed in accordance with the requirements for an FIP
If the SIP serves a specific area, is it located at the main point of entry into that area
Wiring
The extra low voltage wiring of the fire detection and alarm system is be kept separate and distinct from all other systems
The extra low voltage wiring of the fire detection and alarm system is installed in accordance with the requirements of AS/ACIF S009
Other wiring is installed in accordance with the electrical safety requirements of AS/NZS
Externally energized circuits at voltages in excess of extra low voltage, except the power source for CIE, do not enter any CIE enclosure

LM-FOR-50-ITR-303.7 ASD (Aspirated) installation
ITR Pre Commissioning Procedures (1)
Pre Commissioning Procedures
Check the location of installation is as per approved shop drawings and manufactures recommendations
Check the Height of Panel is as per manufactures recommendations and in accordance with the relevant Australian Standards
Confirm operation of auto-reset from FIP is wired through GP relay
Check all wiring connections are tight and secure
Check routing of the conduits are as per approved shop Dwg’s
Check joints are properly glued /sealed and bonded to eliminate any potential air leaks
Check pipe joints at the inlet ports of the scanner are not glued but firmly fitted into air inlet socket to ensure there is no potential air leaks
Check the sensing holes are drilled as per design
Confirm the exhaust has been routed back into the sampling space
Confirm end caps have been installed un-glued to all pipes at a serviceable height and location
Confirm wiring is complete to Action, Minor Urgent, Fault & Fire relays and monitored via the FIP/SHDCIE.
ITR Pre Commissioning Procedures (2)
Pre Commissioning Procedures
Power up the system, the aspirator starts up and air is flowing out of exhaust port , LCD screen is operational.
Induce smoke into the furthest sampling point from the head end unit
Check that a Fire signal is being transmitted to the FIP within 60s of smoke entering the VESDA pipe
Check the correct signals are being transmitted to the FIP via Action, Minor Urgent & Fire Relays correctly.
Remove the power from the VESDA and confirm Fault is received at the FIP
Check the fire signal is conveyed to the fire Alarm system and BMS, if required
Check the transmission of signals to operate ancillary devices, if required.
Record all baseline data as required.
Water Mist Fire Protection System – AS 4587-1999
Prompting Name: Water Mist Fire Protection System – AS 4587-1999

Name: Details
Do the plans accurately illustrate the hazard configuration?
Are all components of the system in compliance with AS4587-1999
Check all flow calculations and verify that the containers, piping and operational equipment are installed and sized in accordance with the plans
Are dimensions of unclosable openings in accordance with the plans?
Check protected area for openings other than those in Item 4
Does the nameplate data on storage containers correlate with the submitted details?
Check quantity and mass of containers
Check protected area volume
Check need for and adequate provision of, post-fire ventilation
Physically check the pipework. Are pipe joints sound and is pipework adequately secured?
Ensure that storage containers are disconnected

Perform a full functional check of system (by operation of detectors) noting correct auxiliary electrical shutdown function (e.g. .....) doors released, dampers shut, airhandlers shut down, etc. (see Note 1)
Ensure that any non fire shutdown plant capable of affecting system performance is operating during the test
Ensure system release(s) operates correctly (see Note 2)
Activate each detector head or system in turn by employing heat, products of combustion, etc. Ensure each manual alarm point operates and transmits
Ensure that the detection and control equipment complies with AS 1670 and AS 1603.4 with respect to configuration and operation
Ensure that visual and audible alarms operate
Ensure that each alarm registers on CIE and mimic panels, if any
Check that air-handling plant shutdown relay is activated

Where multiple alarms are required for system operation, ensure that first and subsequent level alarms operate, including audible and visual indications, auxiliary equipment, and gas release mechanisms, if installed
Check that directional valves are fitted where required and ensure that they operate correctly
Reset the system and check all manual release devices
Reconnect storage containers. Ensure that all caps, plugs and locking pins are removed and that the system is left in an operable condition (see Note 3)

Fire Hydrant Systems (High Rise) – 1050kPa at the highest hydrant in the pressure stage being tested If pressure reading is being taken at the booster, determine the height difference in metres between the top hydrant and the booster and add 10kPa per metre of static pressure to this figure with a minimum test pressure of 1700kPa If in doubt please seek clarification from the Construction Supervisor or the Design Manager
